017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab;
018
019import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
020import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
023import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools;
024
025import java.util.Random;
026
027import static com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils.floor;
028import static com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.Gamut.GAMUT_DATA;
029
030/**
031 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
032 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
033 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
034 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
035 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
036 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components. A slight difference
037 * between Oklab and IPT here is that IPT shrinks the chromatic channels to store their -1 to 1 range in a color float's
038 * 0 to 1 range, then offsets the shrunken range from -0.5 to 0.5, to 0 to 1; Oklab does not need to shrink the range,
039 * and only offsets it in the same way (both just add 0.5).
040 * <br>
041 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
042 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
043 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
044 */
045public class ColorTools {
046        /**
047         * No need to instantiate.
048         */
049        private ColorTools(){
050        }
051        /**
052         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
053         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
054         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with
055         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} as its shader, colors passed with
056         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as Oklab. L should be
057         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
058         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
059         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
060         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
061         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
062         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
063         * <br>
064         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
065         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
066         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
067         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
068         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
069         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
070         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
071         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
072         *
073         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
074         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
075         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
076         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
077         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
078         */
079        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
080                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
081                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
082        }
083
084
085        /**
086         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
087         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
088         * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
089         * case it has in this class, it is never given negative inputs.
090         * <br>
091         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
092         * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
093         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
094         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
095         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
096         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
097         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
098         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
099         * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
100         * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
101         * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
102         * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
103         * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
104         * <br>
105         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
106         * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
107         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
108         */
109        public static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
110                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
111                final float x0 = x;
112                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
113                ix += (ix>>>4);
114                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
115                x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
116                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
117                x  = 0.33333334f*(1.9999999f * x + x0/(x*x));
118                return x;
119        }
120
121        /**
122         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
123         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
124         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
125         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
126         */
127        private static float cube(final float x) {
128                return x * x * x;
129        }
130
131        /**
132         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
133         * Really just {@code component * component}.
134         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
135         * @return a linear version of component
136         */
137        public static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
138                return component * component;
139        }
140
141    /**
142     * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
143     * Really just a float version of the square root of component.
144     * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
145     * @return a non-linear version of component
146     */
147    public static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
148        return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
149    }
150
151        /**
152         * Changes the curve of a requested L value so that it matches the internally-used curve. This takes a curve with a
153         * very-dark area similar to sRGB (a very small one), and makes it significantly larger. This is typically used on
154         * "to Oklab" conversions.
155         * <br>
156         * Internally, this is similar to {@code (float)Math.pow(L, 1.5f)}. At one point it used a modified "Barron spline"
157         * to get its curvature mostly right, but this now seems nearly indistinguishable from an ideal curve.
158         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
159         * @return an adjusted L value that can be used internally
160         */
161        public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
162                return (float) Math.sqrt(L * L * L);
163        }
164
165        /**
166         * Changes the curve of the internally-used lightness when it is output to another format. This makes the very-dark
167         * area smaller, matching (closely) the curve that the standard sRGB lightness uses. This is typically used on "from
168         * Oklab" conversions.
169         * <br>
170         * Internally, this is similar to {@code (float)Math.pow(L, 2f/3f)}. At one point it used a modified "Barron spline"
171         * to get its curvature mostly right, but this now seems nearly indistinguishable from an ideal curve.
172         * <br>
173         * This specific code uses a modified cube root approximation (based on {@link #cbrtPositive(float)}) originally by
174         * Marc B. Reynolds.
175         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
176         * @return an adjusted L value that can be fed into a conversion to RGBA or something similar
177         */
178        public static float reverseLight(float L) {
179                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(L);
180                final float x0 = L;
181                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
182                ix += (ix>>>4);
183                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
184                L  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
185                L  = 0.33333334f * (2f * L + x0/(L*L));
186                L  = 0.33333334f * (1.9999999f * L + x0/(L*L));
187                return L * L;
188        }
189

196//        else
197//            r = (turning * L) / (1e-20f + (L + shape * d));
198//        return r * r * (256f / 255f);

220
221        /**
222         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
223         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
224         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
225         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
226         */
227        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
228        {
229                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
230                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
231                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
232                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
233                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
234                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
235                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
236                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
237                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
238                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
239                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
240        }
241
242        /**
243         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
244         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
245         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
246         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
247         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
248         */
249        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
250        {
251                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
252                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
253                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
254                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
255                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
256                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
257                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
258                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
259                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
260                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
261                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
262        }
263
264        /**
265         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
266         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
267         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
268         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
269         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
270         */
271        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
272        {
273                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
274                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
275                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
276                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
277                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
278                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
279                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
280                editing.r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
281                editing.g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
282                editing.b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
283                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
284                return editing.clamp();
285        }
286
287        /**
288         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
289         * into an Oklab-format Color called {@code editing}. This is mostly useful if the rest of your application expects
290         * colors in Oklab format, such as because you use {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} or {@link ColorfulBatch}.
291         * <br>
292         * Internally, this simply calls {@link Color#abgr8888ToColor(Color, float)} and returns the edited Color.
293         * @param editing a libGDX Color that will be filled in-place with the color {@code oklab}, unchanged from its color space
294         * @param oklab a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
295         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
296         */
297        public static Color toOklabColor(Color editing, final float oklab){
298                Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, oklab);
299                return editing;
300        }
301
302        /**
303         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
304         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
305         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
306         */
307        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
308                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
309                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
310                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
311
312                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
313                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
314                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
315
316                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
317                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
318                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f       ), 0), 255)
319                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
320                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
321                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
322        }
323
324        /**
325         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
326         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
327         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
328         */
329        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
330                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
331                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
332                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
333                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
334                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
335                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
336                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
337                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
338                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
339                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f       ), 0), 255)
340                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
341                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
342                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
343        }
344
345        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
346        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
347        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
348        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
349
350        // shrunken multipliers:
351        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
352        //+0.9889992500 -1.2142961000 +0.2252968500
353        //+0.0129520185 +0.3913858800 -0.4043378800
354
355        /**
356         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
357         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
358         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
359         */
360        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
361                final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
362                final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
363                final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
364                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
365                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
366                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
367                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
368                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
369                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f       ), 0), 255)
370                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
371                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
372                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
373        }
374
375        /**
376         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
377         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
378         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
379         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
380         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
381         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
382         */
383        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
384                r = forwardGamma(r);
385                g = forwardGamma(g);
386                b = forwardGamma(b);
387                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
388                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
389                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
390                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
391                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
392                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f       ), 0), 255)
393                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
394                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
395                                                | ((int)(a * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
396        }
397
398        /**
399         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
400         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
401         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
402         */
403        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
404        {
405                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
406                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
407                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
408                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
409                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
410                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
411                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
412                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
413        }
414
415        /**
416         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
417         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
418         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
419         */
420        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
421        {
422                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
423                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
424                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
425                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
426                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
427                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
428                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
429                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
430        }
431
432        /**
433         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
434         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
435         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
436         */
437        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
438        {
439                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
440                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
441                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
442                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
443                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
444                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
445                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
446                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
447        }
448
449        /**
450         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
451         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
452         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
453         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
454         */
455        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
456        {
457                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
458        }
459
460        /**
461         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
462         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
463         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
464         */
465        public static float red(final float encoded)
466        {
467                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
468                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
469                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
470                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
471                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
472                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
473                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
474                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
475        }
476
477        /**
478         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
479         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
480         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
481         */
482        public static float green(final float encoded)
483        {
484                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
485                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
486                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
487                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
488                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
489                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
490                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
491                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
492        }
493
494        /**
495         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
496         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
497         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
498         */
499        public static float blue(final float encoded)
500        {
501                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
502                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
503                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
504                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
505                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
506                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
507                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
508                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
509        }
510
511        /**
512         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
513         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
514         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
515         */
516        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
517        {
518                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
519        }
520
521        /**
522         * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given Oklab color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
523         * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
524         * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
525         * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
526         * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
527         * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
528         * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
529         * 0 chroma, and the most colorful values (close to cyan) should have 0.334f chroma.
530         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
531         * @return a float between 0.0f and 0.334f that represents how colorful the given value is
532         */
533        public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
534                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
535                final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF)  * 0x1p-8f;
536                final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF) * 0x1p-8f;
537                return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
538        }
539
540        /**
541         * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
542         * combination. This is useful to know the bounds of {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater
543         * than 0.334f .
544         * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
545         * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
546         * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 0.334f
547         */
548        public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness){
549                final int idx = (int) (Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f) * 255.999f) << 8
550                                | (int) (256f * (hue - floor(hue)));
551                return (GAMUT_DATA[idx]) * 0x1p-8f;
552        }
553
554        /**
555         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
556         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
557         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
558         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
559         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
560         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
561         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
562         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
563         * <br>
564         * This method considers its hue, saturation, and lightness parameters as the HSL color space does. You may instead
565         * want the method {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)}, which treats lightness exactly as Oklab does,
566         * and handles hue and saturation with the Oklab color solid (which is shaped oddly) instead of the HSL color solid
567         * (which is a bicone, with a wide cone pointing up attached at the base to another wide cone pointing down).
568         * Using oklabByHSL() should be faster in many cases, and the lightness handling alone may be a reason to use it.
569         * There is also {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which may be preferable if you want a specific
570         * amount of chroma (colorful-ness) and no greater.
571         *
572         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
573         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
574         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
575         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
576         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
577         */
578        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
579                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
580                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
581                } else {
582                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
583                }
584        }
585
586        /**
587         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
588         * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details. It is also
589         * different from {@link #oklabSaturation(float)}, which gets the saturation as Oklab understands it rather than how
590         * HSL understands it.
591         *
592         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
593         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
594         */
595        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
596                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
597                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
598                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
599                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
600                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
601                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
602                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
603                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
604                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
605                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
606                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
607                float x, y, w;
608                if(g < b) {
609                        x = b;
610                        y = g;
611                }
612                else {
613                        x = g;
614                        y = b;
615                }
616                if(r < x) {
617                        w = r;
618                }
619                else {
620                        w = x;
621                        x = r;
622                }
623                return x - Math.min(w, y);
624        }
625
626        /**
627         * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for Oklab. You can
628         * also use {@link #oklabLightness(float)}, which is an alias for channelL(). This ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f
629         * (white).
630         *
631         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
632         * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
633         */
634        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
635                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
636                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
637                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
638                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
639                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
640                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
641                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
642                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
643                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
644                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
645                float x, y, w;
646                if(g < b) {
647                        x = b;
648                        y = g;
649                }
650                else {
651                        x = g;
652                        y = b;
653                }
654                if(r < x) {
655                        w = r;
656                }
657                else {
658                        w = x;
659                        x = r;
660                }
661                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
662                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
663        }
664
665        /**
666         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
667         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased). You can also use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, which
668         * positions the different hues at different values, somewhat, from this, but is more accurate to how Oklab handles
669         * hues.
670         *
671         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
672         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
673         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
674         */
675        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
676                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
677                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
678                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
679                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
680                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
681                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
682                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
683                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
684                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
685                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
686                float x, y, z, w;
687                if(g < b) {
688                        x = b;
689                        y = g;
690                        z = -1f;
691                        w = 2f / 3f;
692                }
693                else {
694                        x = g;
695                        y = b;
696                        z = 0f;
697                        w = -1f / 3f;
698                }
699                if(r < x) {
700                        z = w;
701                        w = r;
702                }
703                else {
704                        w = x;
705                        x = r;
706                }
707                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
708                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
709        }
710
711        /**
712         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
713         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
714         *
715         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
716         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
717         */
718        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
719        {
720                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
721        }
722
723        /**
724         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
725         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
726         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
727         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
728         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
729         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
730         */
731        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
732        {
733                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
734        }
735
736        /**
737         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
738         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
739         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
740         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
741         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
742         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
743         */
744        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
745        {
746                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
747        }
748
749        /**
750         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
751         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not Oklab! Takes
752         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
753         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
754         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different from the
755         * result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
756         * This won't allocate any objects.
757         * <br>
758         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
759         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
760         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
761         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
762         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
763         * <br>
764         * You may want {@link #editOklab(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float)} instead, which
765         * adjusts the L, A, B, and alpha channels directly instead of converting to HSL and back.
766         *
767         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
768         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
769         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
770         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
771         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
772         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
773         */
774        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
775                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
776                final float L = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
777                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
778                if (L <= 0.001f)
779                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
780                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
781                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
782                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
783                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
784                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
785                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
786                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
787                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
788                float x, y, z, w;
789                if(g < b) {
790                        x = b;
791                        y = g;
792                        z = -1f;
793                        w = 2f / 3f;
794                }
795                else {
796                        x = g;
797                        y = b;
798                        z = 0f;
799                        w = -1f / 3f;
800                }
801                if(r < x) {
802                        z = w;
803                        w = r;
804                }
805                else {
806                        w = x;
807                        x = r;
808                }
809                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
810                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
811                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
812                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
813                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
814        }
815
816        /**
817         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
818         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
819         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
820         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
821         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
822         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
823         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
824         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
825         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
826         */
827        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
828                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
829                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
830        }
831
832        /**
833         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
834         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
835         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
836         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
837         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
838         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
839         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
840         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
841         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
842         */
843        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
844                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
845                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
846        }
847
848        /**
849         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
850         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
851         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
852         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
853         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
854         * alpha and L of start as-is.
855         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
856         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
857         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
858         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
859         */
860        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
861                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
862                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
863        }
864
865        /**
866         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
867         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
868         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
869         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
870         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
871         * L of start as-is.
872         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
873         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
874         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
875         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
876         */
877        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
878                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
879                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
880        }
881
882        /**
883         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
884         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
885         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
886         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
887         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
888         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
889         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
890         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
891         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
892         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
893         */
894        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
895                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
896                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
897        }
898
899        /**
900         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
901         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
902         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
903         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
904         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
905         * alpha and L of start as-is.
906         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
907         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
908         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
909         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
910         */
911        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
912                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
913                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
914        }
915
916        /**
917         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
918         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
919         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
920         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
921         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
922         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
923         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
924         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
925         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
926         */
927        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
928                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
929                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
930        }
931
932        /**
933         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
934         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
935         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
936         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
937         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
938         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
939         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
940         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
941         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
942         */
943        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
944                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
945                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
946        }
947
948        /**
949         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
950         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
951         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
952         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
953         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
954         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
955         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
956         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
957         */
958        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
959                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
960                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
961                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
962                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
963                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
964        }
965
966        /**
967         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
968         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
969         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. Higher values for {@code change} can
970         * force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}.
971         * The alpha never changes.
972         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
973         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
974         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
975         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
976         */
977        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
978                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
979                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
980                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
981                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
982                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
983        }
984
985        /**
986         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
987         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
988         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
989         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
990         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
991         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
992         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
993         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
994         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
995         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
996         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
997         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
998         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
999         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1000         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1001         */
1002        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1003        {
1004                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1005                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1006                                L = (bits & 0xff),
1007                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1008                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1009                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1010                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1011                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1012                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
1013                        return mainColor;
1014                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
1015        }
1016
1017        /**
1018         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast
1019         * with, gets a packed float Oklab color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1020         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
1021         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
1022         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1023         * <br>
1024         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1025         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
1026         * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1027         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1028         * @param contrastingColor a packed Oklab float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
1029         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1030         */
1031        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1032        {
1033                final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1034                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
1035        }
1036
1037        /**
1038         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1039         * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1040         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1041         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color
1042         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
1043         */
1044        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1045                final int oklab = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1046                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
1047        }
1048
1049        /**
1050         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1051         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1052         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1053         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
1054         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1055         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1056         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
1057         */
1058        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1059                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1060                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80,
1061                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1062                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
1063                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1064                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1065                                | (eAlpha << 24));
1066        }
1067
1068        /**
1069         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1070         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1071         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1072         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1073         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1074         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1075         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1076         * but only internally for measuring distance).
1077         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
1078         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1079         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1080         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1081         */
1082        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1083                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1084                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1085                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1086                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1087                final float limit = variance * variance;
1088                float dist, x, y, z;
1089                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1090                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1091                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1092                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1093                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1094                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1095                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
1096                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1097                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
1098                }
1099                return color;
1100        }
1101
1102        /**
1103         * Given a 1D int index between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive), this treats the 1D index as two parts (lightness and
1104         * hue angle, both from 0 to 255) and gets the distance from grayscale to the edge of the gamut at that lightness
1105         * and hue. The index can be constructed from a lightness value {@code L} from 0 to 255, and a hue value {@code H}
1106         * from 0 to 255 with: {@code (L << 8 | H)} or the simpler equivalent {@code (L * 256 + H)}. These assume L and H
1107         * have been limited to the 0 to 255 range already. This does not bounds-check index. Because hue is not typically
1108         * measured between 0 and 255, getting that value is a bit different; you can use
1109         * {@link TrigTools#atan2Turns(float, float)} (with an Oklab color's B for y, then its A for x) and multiply it by 256
1110         * to get H.
1111         * <br>
1112         * The distance this returns is a byte between 0 and 84 (both inclusive), as the Euclidean distance from the center
1113         * grayscale value at the lightness in the index, to the edge of the gamut at the same lightness, along the hue in
1114         * the index. This is measured in a space from -1 to 1 for both A and B, with the 0 in the center meaning grayscale,
1115         * and multiplied by 256 to get a meaningful byte value. To return to the A and B values Oklab uses here, you would
1116         * need to use some trigonometry on the hue (if it's in the 0 to 1 range, you can call
1117         * {@link TrigTools#cosTurns(float)} on the hue to almost get A, and {@link TrigTools#sinTurns(float)} to almost get B),
1118         * then multiply each of those by the distance, divide each by 256.0, and add 0.5.
1119         * <br>
1120         * Only intended for the narrow cases where external code needs read-only access to the internal Oklab gamut data.
1121         * The gamut data is quite large (it is in a 71 KB source file containing only the gamut, while the entire IPT_HQ
1122         * ColorTools file is 56 KB, and includes everything else except a gamut table), so it's better to have
1123         * direct read access to it without being able to accidentally rewrite it.
1124         * @param index must be between 0 and 65535; the upper 8 bits are lightness and the lower 8 are hue angle.
1125         * @return a byte (always between 0 and 84, inclusive) representing the Euclidean distance between a grayscale value and the most saturated value possible, using the above measurements
1126         */
1127        public static byte getRawGamutValue(int index){
1128                return GAMUT_DATA[index];
1129        }
1130
1131        /**
1132         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1133         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
1134         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1135         */
1136        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1137        {
1138                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1139                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1140                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1141                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[(decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A))];
1142                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1143        }
1144
1145        /**
1146         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1147         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1148         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1149         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1150         * @return true if the given Oklab channels can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1151         */
1152        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1153        {
1154                A = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1155                B = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1156                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[((int) (L * 255) & 0xFF) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A))];
1157                return L >= 0f && L <= 1f && g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1158
1159                ////This was the old code for this inGamut(), which was subtly different from the other inGamut() when called
1160                /// on a packed float. The packed floats can go ever-so-slightly towards or away from the edge.
1161//              A = (A - 0.5f);
