1162//              B = (B - 0.5f);
1163//              final byte g = GAMUT_DATA[((int)(L * 255.999f) << 8) | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1164//              return g * g * 0x1p-16 >= (A * A + B * B);
1165
1166        }
1167
1168        /**
1169         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1170         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1171         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1172         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; does not need to be in-gamut
1173         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1174         * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
1175         */
1176        public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
1177                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1178                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1179                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1180                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1181                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1182                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1183                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1184                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1185                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1186                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8
1187                );
1188        }
1189        /**
1190         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1191         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1192         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1193         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1194         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1195         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1196         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1197         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1198         * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
1199         * for out-of-gamut colors.
1200         */
1201        public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1202                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1203                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1204                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1205                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1206                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1207                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1208                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1209                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1210                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1211                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1212                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1213                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1214        }
1215
1216        /**
1217         * Gets the hue of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands hue rather than how HSL does.
1218         * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1219         * and 1 (exclusive).
1220         *
1221         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1222         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the Oklab color space
1223         */
1224        public static float oklabHue(final float packed) {
1225                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1226                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1227                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1228                return TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1229        }
1230
1231        /**
1232         * Gets the saturation of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands saturation rather than how HSL does.
1233         * Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue and
1234         * lightness, and is between 0 and 1 almost all the time. Saturation should always be between 0 (inclusive) and 1
1235         * (inclusive).
1236         *
1237         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1238         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the Oklab color space
1239         */
1240        public static float oklabSaturation(final float packed) {
1241                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1242                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1243                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1244                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1245                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1246                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];
1247                return dist <= 2.5f ? 0f : (float) Math.sqrt(A * A + B * B) * 2f / (dist);
1248        }
1249
1250        /**
1251         * Gets the lightness of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
1252         * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1253         * and 1 (inclusive).
1254         * <br>
1255         * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
1256         *
1257         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1258         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the Oklab color space
1259         */
1260        public static float oklabLightness(final float packed){
1261                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
1262        }
1263
1264        /**
1265         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
1266         * but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This is more efficient than
1267         * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}, but for colors with less than 0.5f lightness, it can be very
1268         * unpredictable in how it handles saturation. Most colors between 0.5 and 0.75 hue that also have less than 0.5
1269         * lightness are extremely desaturated and close to gray, regardless of what you give for saturation, and these
1270         * colors suddenly jump to very saturated around 0.75 hue and higher. To avoid this issue, you may prefer using
1271         * {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation here
1272         * (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
1273         * <br>
1274         * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
1275         * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
1276         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1277         * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
1278         * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, {@link #oklabSaturation(float)},
1279         * and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
1280         * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1281         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1282         * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
1283         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1284         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1285         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
1286         */
1287        public static float oklabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
1288                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1289                saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
1290                hue -= floor(hue);
1291                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1292                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1293                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * saturation * 0.5f;
1294                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1295                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1296                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1297                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1298                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f)));
1299        }
1300
1301        /**
1302         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
1303         * color but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
1304         * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
1305         * (saturation is what {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different value
1306         * for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the method
1307         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1308         * {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
1309         * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
1310         * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
1311         * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)},
1312         * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
1313         * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1314         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1315         * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
1316         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1317         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1318         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
1319         */
1320        public static float oklabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
1321                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1322                chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f);
1323                hue -= floor(hue);
1324                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1325                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1326                final float dist = Math.min(chroma * 127.5f, GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f);
1327                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1328                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1329                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1330                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1331                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f)));
1332        }
1333
1334        /**
1335         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1336         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1337         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
1338         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1339         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1340         */
1341        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1342                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1343                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1344                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1345                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1346                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1347                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1348                if (dist * dist >= (A * A + B * B))
1349                        return packed;
1350                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1351                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1352                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1353                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8
1354                );
1355        }
1356
1357        /**
1358         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1359         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is. This always produces
1360         * an opaque color.
1361         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1362         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1363         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1364         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1365         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1366         */
1367        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1368                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1369        }
1370        /**
1371         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1372         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1373         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1374         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1375         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1376         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1377         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1378         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1379         */
1380        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1381                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1382                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
1383                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
1384                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1385                final float A2 = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1386                final float B2 = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1387                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B2, A2);
1388                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1389                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1390                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A2 * A2 + B2 * B2))
1391                        return oklab(L, A, B, alpha);
1392                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1393                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1394                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1395                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1396                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1397        }
1398
1399        /**
1400         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1401         * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1402         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
1403         * resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1404         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1405         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1406         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1407         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1408         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1409         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1410         */
1411        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
1412                return editOklab(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1413        }
1414        /**
1415         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by
1416         * the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means
1417         * the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to
1418         * the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1419         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any
1420         * "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5 range, so if you
1421         * multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply
1422         * by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting
1423         * color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1424         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1425         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1426         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1427         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1428         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1429         * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
1430         * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1431         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1432         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1433         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1434         */
1435        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
1436                                                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
1437                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1438                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1439                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1440                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1441                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1442
1443                L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1444                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1445                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1446                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1447                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1448                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1449                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1450                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A * A + B * B))
1451                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1452                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1453                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1454                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1455                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1456                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1457        }
1458
1459        /**
1460         * Multiplies the A and B channels of {@code encoded} by {@code mul}. Typically, mul is non-negative, but if it is
1461         * negative, that will do some amount of inversion of A and B.
1462         * @param encoded a packed float color
1463         * @param mul how much to multiply the chromatic channels of {@code encoded} by
1464         * @return a packed float color that should already be in-gamut
1465         */
1466        public static float multiplyChroma(float encoded, float mul) {
1467                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1468                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1469                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1470                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1471                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1472
1473                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mul, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1474                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mul, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1475                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1476                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1477                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1478                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A * A + B * B))
1479                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1480                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1481                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1482                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1483                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1484                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1485        }
1486
1487        /**
1488         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1489         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1490         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1491         */
1492        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1493                float L = random.nextFloat();
1494                float A = random.nextFloat();
1495                float B = random.nextFloat();
1496                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1497                        L = random.nextFloat();
1498                        A = random.nextFloat();
1499                        B = random.nextFloat();
1500                }
1501                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1502        }
1503
1504        /**
1505         * Gets the squared Euclidean distance between two colors as packed Oklab floats. This is a very approximate measure
1506         * of how different two colors are from each other, but in Oklab this measurement is relatively more accurate than
1507         * if you used plain RGB as the color space, or even IPT_HQ. The result should typically be rather small; lightness
1508         * can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most (from black to white), and the A and B channels are usually just a
1509         * tiny bit away from the vertical lightness axis. A result of 1 may be the largest this can produce, but it is very
1510         * possible that somewhat larger results can happen. Note that this is squared, so it isn't an admissible metric for
1511         * some usage, like summing up distances.
1512         * @param encodedA a packed Oklab float
1513         * @param encodedB a packed Oklab float
1514         * @return the squared Euclidean distance between encodedA and encodedB; usually less than 1.0f
1515         */
1516        public static float distanceSquared(final float encodedA, final float encodedB) {
1517                final int decodedA = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encodedA);
1518                final float LA = reverseLight((decodedA & 0xff) / 255f);
1519                final float AA = ((decodedA >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1520                final float BA = ((decodedA >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1521                final int decodedB = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encodedB);
1522                final float LDiff = reverseLight((decodedB & 0xff) / 255f) - LA;
1523                final float ADiff = ((decodedB >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f - AA;
1524                final float BDiff = ((decodedB >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f - BA;
1525                return LDiff * LDiff + ADiff * ADiff + BDiff * BDiff;
1526        }
1527
1528        /**
1529         * Gets the actual Euclidean distance between two colors as packed Oklab floats. This is an approximate measure
1530         * of how different two colors are from each other, but in Oklab this measurement is relatively more accurate than
1531         * if you used plain RGB as the color space, or even IPT_HQ. The result should typically be rather small; lightness
1532         * can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most (from black to white), and the A and B channels are usually just a
1533         * tiny bit away from the vertical lightness axis. A result of 1 may be the largest this can produce, but it is very
1534         * possible that somewhat larger results can happen.
1535         * @param encodedA a packed Oklab float
1536         * @param encodedB a packed Oklab float
1537         * @return the Euclidean distance between encodedA and encodedB; usually less than 1.0f
1538         */
1539        public static float distance(final float encodedA, final float encodedB) {
1540                return (float) Math.sqrt(distanceSquared(encodedA, encodedB));
1541        }
1542}
